snippet: Once ambitious American plans for ending the war in Afghanistan are now being replaced by the far more modest goal of setting the stage for Afghans to work out a deal among themselves.
abstract: United States fails to broker meaningful peace talks with the Taliban, underscoring the fragility of the gains claimed during the surge of American troops ordered by Pres Obama in 2009; American plans will instead target a far more modest goal of securing talks between the group and the Afghan government, a deal that will eventually require approval from Pakistan.

byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ROD NORDLAND
byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Sangar Rahimi from Kabul.

lead_paragraph: Once ambitious American plans for ending the war in Afghanistan are now being replaced by the far more modest goal of setting the stage for Afghans to work out a deal among themselves.

headline.seo: U.S. Scales Back Plans for Afghan Peace
headline.main: U.S. Abandoning Hopes for Taliban Peace Deal
headline.print_headline: U.S. Abandoning Hopes for Taliban Peace Deal

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
